custom_item_1.description: Check if Cisco IOS 12 is installed

custom_item_2.info: This command enables the AAA access control system.
custom_item_2.solution:
Globally enable authentication, authorization and accounting (AAA) using the new-model command.
    hostname(config)#aaa new-model

custom_item_3.info: Sets authentication, authorization and accounting (AAA) authentication at login.
custom_item_3.solution:
Configure AAA authentication method(s) for login authentication.
    hostname(config)#aaa authentication login {default | aaa_list_name} [passwd-expiry] method1 [method2]

custom_item_4.info: Authenticates users who access privileged EXEC mode when they use the enable command.
custom_item_4.solution:
Configure AAA authentication method(s) for enable authentication.
    hostname(config)#aaa authentication enable default {method1} enable

custom_item_5.description: Check for aaa auth login default

custom_item_6.info: Authenticates users who access the router or switch using the serial console port.

custom_item_7.description: Check for existence of line tty

custom_item_8.info: Authenticates users who access the router or switch using the TTY port.

custom_item_9.info: Authenticates users who access the router or switch remotely through the VTY port.

custom_item_10.description: 1.2.1 Set 'privilege 1' for local users - 'No users with privileges 2-15'
custom_item_10.info: Sets the privilege level for the user.
custom_item_10.solution:
Set the local user to privilege level 1.
    hostname(config)#usernameprivilege 1

custom_item_11.description: 1.2.2 Set 'transport input ssh' for 'line vty' connections
custom_item_11.solution:
Apply SSH to transport input on all VTY management lines
    hostname(config)#line vtyhostname(config-line)#transport input ssh

custom_item_13.info: The 'no exec' command restricts a line to outgoing connections only.
custom_item_13.solution:
Disable the EXEC process on the auxiliary port.
    hostname(config)#line aux 0
    hostname(config-line)#no exec

custom_item_14.description: 1.2.4 Create 'access-list' for use with 'line vty' - 'ACL permit tcp is configured'
custom_item_14.info: Access lists control the transmission of packets on an interface, control Virtual Terminal Line (VTY) access, and restrict the contents of routing updates. The Cisco IOS software stops checking the extended access list after a match occurs.
custom_item_14.solution:
Configure the VTY ACL that will be used to restrict management access to the device.
    hostname(config)#access-listpermit tcpany
    hostname(config)#access-listpermit tcp hostany
    hostname(config)#deny ip any any log

custom_item_15.description: 1.2.4 Create 'access-list' for use with 'line vty' - 'ACL deny is configured'
custom_item_15.info: Access lists control the transmission of packets on an interface, control Virtual Terminal Line (VTY) access, and restrict the contents of routing updates. The Cisco IOS software stops checking the extended access list after a match occurs.
custom_item_15.solution:
Configure the VTY ACL that will be used to restrict management access to the device.
    hostname(config)#access-listpermit tcpany
    hostname(config)#access-listpermit tcp hostany
    hostname(config)#deny ip any any log

custom_item_16.info: The 'access-class' setting restricts incoming and outgoing connections between a particular vty (into a Cisco device) and the networking devices associated with addresses in an access list.
custom_item_16.solution:
Configure remote management access control restrictions for all VTY lines.
    hostname(config)#line vtyhostname(config-line)# access-classin

custom_item_17.description: 1.2.6 Set 'exec-timeout' to less than or equal to 10 minutes for 'line aux 0'
custom_item_17.info: If no input is detected during the interval, the EXEC facility resumes the current connection. If no connections exist, the EXEC facility returns the terminal to the idle state and disconnects the incoming session.
custom_item_17.solution:
Configure device timeout (10 minutes or less) to disconnect sessions after a fixed idle time.
    hostname(config)#line aux 0
    hostname(config-line)#exec-timeout

custom_item_18.description: 1.2.7 Set 'exec-timeout' to less than or equal to 10 minutes 'line console 0'
custom_item_18.info: If no input is detected during the interval, the EXEC facility resumes the current connection. If no connections exist, the EXEC facility returns the terminal to the idle state and disconnects the incoming session.
custom_item_18.solution:
Configure device timeout (10 minutes or less) to disconnect sessions after a fixed idle time.
    hostname(config)#line con 0
    hostname(config-line)#exec-timeout

custom_item_19.description: 1.2.8 Set 'exec-timeout' less than or equal to 10 minutes 'line tty'
custom_item_19.info: If no input is detected during the interval, the EXEC facility resumes the current connection. If no connections exist, the EXEC facility returns the terminal to the idle state and disconnects the incoming session.
custom_item_19.solution:
Configure device timeout (10 minutes or less) to disconnect sessions after a fixed idle time.
    hostname(config)#line tty {line_number} [ending_line_number]
    hostname(config-line)#exec-timeout

custom_item_20.description: 1.2.9 Set 'exec-timeout' to less than or equal to 10 minutes 'line vty'
custom_item_20.info: If no input is detected during the interval, the EXEC facility resumes the current connection. If no connections exist, the EXEC facility returns the terminal to the idle state and disconnects the incoming session.
custom_item_20.solution:
Configure device timeout (10 minutes or less) to disconnect sessions after a fixed idle time.
    hostname(config)#line vty {line_number} [ending_line_number]
    hostname(config-line)#exec-timeout

custom_item_22.info: When you want to allow only an outgoing connection on a line, use the no exec command.
custom_item_22.solution:
Disable the inbound connections on the auxiliary port.
    hostname(config)#line aux 0
    hostname(config-line)#transport input none

custom_item_23.info:
This command specifies a message to be displayed when an EXEC process is created (a line is activated, or an incoming connection is made to a vty). Follow this command with one or more blank spaces and a delimiting character of your choice. Then enter one or more lines of text, terminating the message with the second occurrence of the delimiting character.
    When a user connects to a router, the message-of-the-day (MOTD) banner appears first, followed by the login banner and prompts. After the user logs in to the router, the EXEC banner or incoming banner will be displayed, depending on the type of connection. For a reverse Telnet login, the incoming banner will be displayed. For all other connections, the router will display the EXEC banner.
custom_item_23.solution:
Configure the EXEC banner presented to a user when accessing the devices enable prompt.
    hostname(config)#banner exec c
    Enter TEXT message. End with the character 'c'.c

custom_item_24.info:
Follow the banner login command with one or more blank spaces and a delimiting character of your choice. Then enter one or more lines of text, terminating the message with the second occurrence of the delimiting character.
    When a user connects to the router, the message-of-the-day (MOTD) banner (if configured) appears first, followed by the login banner and prompts. After the user successfully logs in to the router, the EXEC banner or incoming banner will be displayed, depending on the type of connection. For a reverse Telnet login, the incoming banner will be displayed. For all other connections, the router will display the EXEC banner.
custom_item_24.solution:
Configure the device so a login banner presented to a user attempting to access the device.
    hostname(config)#banner login c
    Enter TEXT message. End with the character 'c'.c

custom_item_25.info:
This MOTD banner is displayed to all terminals connected and is useful for sending messages that affect all users (such as impending system shutdowns). Use the no exec-banner or no motd-banner command to disable the MOTD banner on a line. The no exec-banner command also disables the EXEC banner on the line.
    When a user connects to the router, the MOTD banner appears before the login prompt. After the user logs in to the router, the EXEC banner or incoming banner will be displayed, depending on the type of connection. For a reverse Telnet login, the incoming banner will be displayed. For all other connections, the router will display the EXEC banner.
custom_item_25.solution:
Configure the message of the day (MOTD) banner presented when a user first connects to the device.
    hostname(config)#banner motd c
    Enter TEXT message. End with the character 'c'.c

custom_item_26.info: Use the enable secret command to provide an additional layer of security over the enable password. The enable secret command provides better security by storing the enable secret password using a nonreversible cryptographic function. The added layer of security encryption provides is useful in environments where the password crosses the network or is stored on a TFTP server.
custom_item_26.solution:
Configure a strong, enable secret password.
    hostname(config)#enable secret

custom_item_27.info: When password encryption is enabled, the encrypted form of the passwords is displayed when a more system:running-config command is entered.
custom_item_27.solution:
Enable password encryption service to protect sensitive access passwords in the device configuration.
    hostname(config)#service password-encryption

custom_item_28.description: 1.4.3 Set 'username secret' for all local users
custom_item_28.info:
Use the username secret command to configure a username and MD5-encrypted user password. MD5 encryption is a strong encryption method that is not retrievable; thus, you cannot use MD5 encryption with protocols that require clear-text passwords, such as Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP).
    The username secret command provides an additional layer of security over the username password. It also provides better security by encrypting the password using non reversible MD5 encryption and storing the encrypted text. The added layer of MD5 encryption is useful in environments in which the password crosses the network or is stored on a TFTP server.
custom_item_28.solution:
Create a local user with an encrypted, complex (not easily guessed) password.
    hostname(config)#usernamesecret

custom_item_30.description: 1.5.1 Set 'no snmp-server' to disable SNMP when unused
custom_item_30.info: If not in use, disable simple network management protocol (SNMP), read and write access.
custom_item_30.solution:
Disable SNMP read and write access if not in used to monitor and/or manage device.
      hostname(config)#no snmp-server

custom_item_31.info: An SNMP community string permits read-only access to all objects.
custom_item_31.solution:
Disable the default SNMP community string 'private'
      hostname(config)#no snmp-server community {private}

custom_item_32.info: An SNMP community string permits read-only access to all objects.
custom_item_32.solution:
Disable the default SNMP community string 'public'
      hostname(config)#no snmp-server community {public}

custom_item_33.description: 1.5.4 Do not set 'RW' for any 'snmp-server community'
custom_item_33.info: Specifies read-write access. Authorized management stations can both retrieve and modify MIB objects.
custom_item_33.solution:
Disable SNMP write access.
      hostname(config)#no snmp-server community {write_community_string}

custom_item_34.description: 1.5.5 Set the ACL for each 'snmp-server community'
custom_item_34.info: This feature specifies a list of IP addresses that are allowed to use the community string to gain access to the SNMP agent.
custom_item_34.solution:
Configure authorized SNMP community string and restrict access to authorized management systems.
      hostname(config)#snmp-server communityro {snmp_access-list_number | snmp_access-list_name}

custom_item_35.description: 1.5.6 Create an 'access-list' for use with SNMP - 'SNMP permit secured by ACL'
custom_item_35.info: You can use access lists to control the transmission of packets on an interface, control Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) access, and restrict the contents of routing updates. The Cisco IOS software stops checking the extended access list after a match occurs.
custom_item_35.solution:
Configure SNMP ACL for restricting access to the device from authorized management stations segmented in a trusted management zone.
      hostname(config)#access-listpermithostname(config)#access-list deny any log

custom_item_36.description: 1.5.6 Create an 'access-list' for use with SNMP - 'SNMP deny secured by ACL'
custom_item_36.info: You can use access lists to control the transmission of packets on an interface, control Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) access, and restrict the contents of routing updates. The Cisco IOS software stops checking the extended access list after a match occurs.
custom_item_36.solution:
Configure SNMP ACL for restricting access to the device from authorized management stations segmented in a trusted management zone.
      hostname(config)#access-listpermithostname(config)#access-list deny any log

custom_item_38.info: SNMP notifications can be sent as traps to authorized management systems.
custom_item_38.solution:
Configure authorized SNMP trap community string and restrict sending messages to authorized management systems.
      hostname(config)#snmp-server host {ip_address} {trap_community_string} snmp

custom_item_39.info: SNMP notifications can be sent as traps to authorized management systems.
custom_item_39.solution:
Enable SNMP traps.
      hostname(config)#snmp-server enable traps snmp authentication linkup linkdown coldstart

custom_item_40.info: The hostname is used in prompts and default configuration filenames.
custom_item_40.solution:
Configure an appropriate host name for the router.
    hostname(config)#hostname {router_name}

custom_item_41.info: Define a default domain name that the Cisco IOS software uses to complete unqualified hostnames
custom_item_41.solution:
Configure an appropriate domain name for the router.
    hostname (config)#ip domain name {domain-name}

custom_item_42.description: 2.1.1.1.3 Set 'modulus' to greater than or equal to 2048 for 'crypto key generate rsa'
custom_item_42.info:
Use this command to generate RSA key pairs for your Cisco device. RSA keys are generated in pairs--one public RSA key and one private RSA key.

     NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

     NOTE: If performing an offline config audit this check may not show results.
custom_item_42.solution:
Generate an RSA key pair for the router.
    hostname(config)#crypto key generate rsa general-keys modulus 2048

custom_item_43.info: The time interval that the router waits for the SSH client to respond before disconnecting an uncompleted login attempt.
custom_item_43.solution:
Configure the SSH timeout
     hostname(config)#ip ssh time-out [60]

custom_item_44.description: 2.1.1.1.5 Set maximimum value for 'ip ssh authentication-retries'
custom_item_44.info: The number of retries before the SSH login session disconnects.
custom_item_44.solution:
Configure the SSH timeout:
    hostname(config)#ip ssh authentication-retries [3]

custom_item_45.info: Specify the version of Secure Shell (SSH) to be run on a router
custom_item_45.solution:
Configure the router to use SSH version 2
    hostname(config)#ip ssh version 2

custom_item_46.info: Disable Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) service at device level.
custom_item_46.solution:
Disable Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) service globally.
    hostname(config)#no cdp run

custom_item_47.info: Disable the Bootstrap Protocol (BOOTP) service on your routing device.
custom_item_47.solution:
Disable the bootp server.
    hostname(config)#no ip bootp server

custom_item_48.info: Disable the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server and relay agent features on your router.
custom_item_48.solution:
Disable the DHCP server.
    hostname(config)#no service dhcp

custom_item_49.solution:
Disable the ident server.
    hostname(config)#no ip identd

custom_item_50.info: Generate keepalive packets on idle incoming network connections.
custom_item_50.solution:
Enable TCP keepalives-in service:
    hostname(config)#service tcp-keepalives-in

custom_item_51.info: Generate keepalive packets on idle outgoing network connections.
custom_item_51.solution:
Enable TCP keepalives-in service:
    hostname(config)#service tcp-keepalives-out

custom_item_52.solution:
Disable the PAD service.
    hostname(config)#no service pad

custom_item_54.info: Enable system message logging to a local buffer.
custom_item_54.solution:
Configure buffered logging (with minimum size). Recommended size is 64000.
    hostname(config)#logging buffered [log_buffer_size]

custom_item_55.info: Verify logging to device console is enabled and limited to a rational severity level to avoid impacting system performance and management.
custom_item_55.solution:
Configure console logging level.
    hostname(config)#logging console critical

custom_item_56.info: Log system messages and debug output to a remote host.
custom_item_56.solution:
Designate one or more syslog servers by IP address.
    hostname(config)#logging host syslog_server

custom_item_57.info: Limit messages logged to the syslog servers based on severity level informational.
custom_item_57.solution:
Configure SNMP trap and syslog logging level.
    hostname(config)#logging trap informational

custom_item_58.info: Configure the system to apply a time stamp to debugging messages or system logging messages
custom_item_58.solution:
Configure debug messages to include timestamps.
    hostname(config)#service timestamps debug datetime {msec} show-timezone

custom_item_59.info: Specify the source IPv4 or IPv6 address of system logging packets
custom_item_59.solution:
Bind logging to the loopback interface.
    hostname(config)#logging source-interface loopback {loopback_interface_number}

custom_item_60.info: Use this command if you want to allow the system to synchronize the system software clock with the specified NTP server.
custom_item_60.solution:
Configure at least one external NTP Server using the following commands
    hostname(config)#ntp server {ip address}

custom_item_61.info: Disable the handling of IP datagrams with source routing header options.
custom_item_61.solution:
Disable source routing.
    hostname(config)#no ip source-route
